title: 107_s2187
content: The Act titled "Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002" authorizes the Department to provide health care during major disasters and medical emergencies. The Department of Veterans Affairs can provide hospital care and medical services during major disasters and emergencies, regardless of veterans' enrollment status. This is authorized under the "Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002." The Secretary may prioritize care for certain groups over others in VA medical facilities, except for veterans with service-connected disabilities and active duty members receiving health care under a specific section. Reimbursement for care provided to non-Department officers or employees will be agreed upon with their respective department heads. Amounts received will be credited to the facility providing the care. In case of a disaster or emergency, care must be provided within 60 days. The Secretary must report to Congress on the allocation of facilities and personnel for providing care and services under this section. Regulations will be prescribed for governing the Secretary's authority. During major disasters and medical emergencies, the Secretary may provide emergency care without charges. Members of the Armed Forces can receive hospital care and medical services during war, national emergencies, or disasters. The Secretary has the authority to furnish care and services in these situations. During major disasters or emergencies, the Secretary may prioritize providing care and services under specific circumstances. The terms 'hospital care', 'nursing home care', and 'medical services' are defined in this section.
